Alan Turing Alan Turing (1912-1954) was an English mathematician, computer scientist, and cryptographer who played a fundamental role in the development of computer science. He was also the first person to be convicted of homosexual offences under the law in the United Kingdom. Turing was born in London, England, and was educated at Sherborne School, an independent school in Dorset. He then studied at King's College, Cambridge, where he was a member of the Cambridge Apostles, and was awarded a doctorate in mathematics in 1936. Turing worked at the National Physical Laboratory (NPL) in London during the Second World War, where he helped to develop the first computer, the ACE. After the war, Turing worked at the University of Manchester, and then at the University of Cambridge, where he developed the first theoretical model of a computer. Turing was also the first person to be prosecuted for homosexual offences in the UK. He was convicted of gross indecency in 1952 and was given a chemical castration sentence, which he accepted. He died in 1954, aged 41, after taking cyanide. Turing is widely considered to be the father of computer science, and he is also credited with pioneering the theory of artificial intelligence.

Roosevelt Franklin Delano Roosevelt (January 30, 1882 – April 12, 1945) was an American statesman and political leader who served as the 32nd President of the United States from 1933 to 1945. A Democrat, he won a record four presidential elections and became a central figure in world events during the mid-20th century. He directed the United States government during most of the Great Depression and World War II, and is often considered to have been one of the greatest U.S. presidents. Roosevelt was born in 1882 to an old New York family from the Hudson Valley. He attended the elite boarding school Phillips Exeter Academy and then Harvard College, where he became a member of the prestigious Porcellian Club. After graduating from college in 1904, Roosevelt worked as a journalist for the New York Evening Post. He entered politics in 1910, serving in the New York State Senate and as Assistant Secretary of the Navy under President Woodrow Wilson. In 1920, Roosevelt was elected governor of New York, and two years later he was elected president of the United States, defeating Republican incumbent Herbert Hoover. Roosevelt took office during the Great Depression, and during his four terms as president, he enacted many programs to combat the economic crisis. These programs were known as the New Deal, which helped to revive the economy and make America the world's leading economic power. In 1940, Roosevelt was elected to a fourth term, becoming the only U.S. president to serve more than two terms. In 1945, Roosevelt died of a cerebral hemorrhage two days after victory in the presidential election, making him the only U.S. president to die in office. Roosevelt has consistently ranked as one of the greatest U.S. presidents.

It is the largest war memorial in the world, and has been called the "National Monument of the American People". The memorial consists of a wall of black granite and stainless steel, measuring 5,500 feet (1,600 m) long, 2,000 feet (610 m) wide, and 85 feet (26 m) high. The wall is inscribed with the names of more than 58,000 U.S. military personnel who died in the Vietnam War. The wall is flanked by two eternal flames, one representing the North and the other the South, and a reflecting pool. The thermosphere is the layer of the Earth's atmosphere directly above the mesosphere and below the exosphere. Within this layer of the atmosphere, ultraviolet radiation causes photoionization/photodissociation of molecules, creating ions in the ionosphere. Taking its name from the Greek θερμός (pronounced "thermos") meaning heat, the thermosphere begins at about 80 km (50 mi) above sea level. Thermospheric temperatures increase with altitude due to absorption of highly energetic solar radiation. He was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1987 and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1998. White retired from touring in 2003, but continued to write and produce music.
